p.s:
is a city in
Eastern Anatolia
, in the far southeastern corner of the
country
.
The city of Hakkari itself is nothing to write home about .
Lots of army quarters but everyday life seems pretty normal .

Getting there makes it worth the trip , as you are literally in the
most
remote city of the country , near the corner where Turkish ,
Iranian
, and
Iraqi
borders meet .
People seem to be indifferent to tourists ( or perhaps just a little cautious ) but usually react in a friendly way if you want to take their pictures .

You will hear very little
Turkish
.

Almost everybody in the streets speaks
Kurdish
.

Before
World War I
, the surrounding mountainous area was densely populated by the
Chaldeans
, who still call the area home to a smaller degree .

The Chaldeans are Eastern Catholics who reverted to communion with the Roman Catholic Church after the schism of 1552 , when they broke from the Syriac Orthodox Church , which in its turn broke from mainstream
Christianity
in the schism of 431 that came about after the Council of
Ephesus
.

In 1692 , a smaller group of Chaldeans ( re-)broke their communion with Rome , declaring themselves to be the members of the Assyrian Church of the East , an independent Eastern Christian denomination with a patriarchate in the village of Qodchanis ( modern Konak ) , northeast of Hakkari . ( In 1918 , the patriarchate was moved to
Iraqi Kurdistan
, and the former church in Qodchanis now lays in ruins . )
Frequent buses from Van make Hakkari easily accessible .
As Hakkari is not a big place most of the town is within walking distance . ( But do read the " Stay safe " passage . ) It does spread out , however , over various hills .
Hakkari has three hotels .
None of them has its own website .

Central , somewhat dark and very sparse but OK for backpackers .
Better speak Turkish or use sign language .
You might be offered an inside room without a window .

Ask for a
pencere
(
payn-JAY-ray
) , which means window .
Cheap at 20-25 TL .
( the former Ümit Hotel ) , Altay Caddesi 15 , ☏ +90438 211-25-05 , fax : +90438 211-24-69 .
This 3-star hotel is pretty modern and pretty good value for money .
Make sure you get to see the room before you book .

It offers street view , mountain view ,
and
the wall of the building next door .
Negotiate .
They expect you to haggle .
They might start with 80 TL/person .
Try to settle for 60 .
But if you have the right room , you will enjoy the clean room with TV and fridge and spacious bathrooms with shower cabin and a western-style WC .
Mind your step when you leave the elevator on the ground floor .
Steps could be slippery .
This 3-star hotel is more old fashioned but also has spacious rooms .
Try to get one at the front for a good view of the main drag .

p.s: Travelling there is pretty safe as long as you stick to the main roads and/or use public transport .
Going for a wild walk ( to take pictures ) on your own even to the top of one of the hills close to the city could let you end up next to a military zone .

That could be
very
unpleasant as you may be thought to be a PKK agent and treated as such .
You should always have your passport or ID with you .
To a frustrated and rightly fearful soldier in these regions ( not the most comfortable place to be deployed ) , it seems to be difficult to differentiate between a tourist and a terrorist .

438
is the area code for Hakkari .

There are several buses to
Van
daily leaving from the city centre to all sorts of places .

The only bus southwest to
Şırnak
leaves pretty early in the morning ( 7AM ) , though .
Check with big bus companies like Vangölü ☏ +904382114324 or Best Van ☏ +904382116734 .
Due to the regional conflicts there might be ID controls on the buses .
In case of bombings roads might also be closed , so do not rely on too tight a schedule .
